												With David Bowie's recent passing, I'd imagine a lot of people will be learning about this game that were unaware of it before Omikron is a game I've tried to complete several times now, but I doubt I ever will. It's really a shame, because on top of it having both Quantic Dream and David Bowie attached to it, it has some pretty interesting ideas, like being an open-world adventure game that combines multiple combat genres and a neat resurrection mechanic where during certain parts of the game your death will result in your soul (described in the game as being your own, real-world soul, transferred into the game as a trap) moving into a different character with new stats. Unfortunately, the game was just too ahead of its time, and as such almost every aspect of the game is flawed in some way. The standard adventure mode plays out like an extremely clunky version of Quantic Dream's later games (like Fahrenheit and Heavy Rain), but the cities are terribly designed and the signs are written in a font that I can only assume was designed to be incomprehensible until you stare at it for several minutes, and as such the only way to reliably travel is by taxi, which essentially defeats the purpose of a open world, let alone the issues I had later on where addresses I had read wouldn't show up as destinations at all. The FPS segments are arguably the only part of the game that works the way you'd expect, but they still feel sluggish and the controls aren't that great. The fighting game portions are the real nightmare, since those are usually the parts where you can be truly "killed"; they play out as if the developers got completely trash-face wasted and then played tekken until they passed out and used that as their inspirational focus, and while there does seem to be some form of a combo system in the game, it doesn't tell you how to use it, and the controls are slow enough that I probably couldn't manage them anyways, so every fight is really just a test to see how quickly you can successfully do a downward leg sweep to known the enemy off their feet and then keep doing it over and over in a stunlock until they die. I would love to finish this game, because even though he barely seems to appear in the game outside of concerts I would love to listen to more of David Bowie's acting, and the story seems legitimately interesting, but the game is just practically unplayable, and even though I make it a little bit further each time I pick it back up I doubt I'll ever manage to finish it without giving up. This is the sort of game that I would love to see remade by Quantic Dream now that they have the tech, but I doubt they ever will. Ultimately, if you want to remember David Bowie, you're better off rewatching Labyrinth instead of playing this game.

												***English Version***(Sorry, nie będzie polskiej wersji, nie mieści się. Chciałem umieścić w komentarzach ale jest limit 1000 znaków)Omikron: The Nomad Soul is the first game of the Quantic Dream studio. It might as well be considered three games in one. For the major part of the gameplay it remains a TPP adventure game relying on the usual stuff:  talking with NPCs and using items. Occasionally it switches to FPP shooter or hand to hand 1 on 1 brawler kind of similar to early instalments of the Tekken or Virtua Fighter series. It is worth mentioning that all of these are made pretty solid and none of them feels like it was forced into the gameplay without a reason (well, maybe with the exception of swimming, but it occurs 2 or 3 times in the entire game, which is acceptable).      An interesting mechanic incorporated into the gameplay is the switching of the protagonist’s bodies. While it is not possible to reincarnate into any NPC, there certainly is a significant number of possible bodies the ‘Nomad Soul’ can possess. Some of these are plot induced – when your actual shell is killed, you will take over the first person that touches the dead body – yes, dying does not necessarily mean  seeing a game over screen.  Later on you acquire a spell that allows reincarnation whenever you find an interesting host – for instance to gain access to a particular area. Or just for fun. I find it a bit disappointing that, while all of these NPCs have their statistics (eg. Strength, speed, HP, MP) and some information on their background, likes and dislikes, when you decide to reincarnate, your previous host simply disappears. At no point it is mentioned that what you actually do is stealing the bodies of living people. I believe that this theme is not sufficiently explored or developed during the game.    Surprisingly enough, the graphics of this game are not all that bad (considering the fact it was published in 1999). Of course, models and  textures are simple and the viewing distance is obscured by the mist,  but all of the game’s districts have their own style and color palette that catches the eye. Furthermore, the way the districts look contributes greatly to the  game’s cyberpunk atmosphere. On the other hand, it is noticeable that there are very few models of NPC characters on the street (2 – 3 per district) and vehicles (1 model of a hovercraft-car and 1 bike –  that’s all!). If you decide to play, I strongly suggest overriding the game’s settings in your graphic card’s panel and forcing every possible filtering on – it greatly improves the game’s appearance: especially the character’s faces during the conversations. Quite obviously, music is where the game excels (David Bowie!) . It needs to be said that not only the tracks featuring David Bowie are awesome (look around the city – you may find a concert going on. ) but the entirety of the soundtrack is an impressive work.In my mini-reviews I usually do not discuss the game’s story line, and this case should not be an exception. But let me tell you that: at some points of the storyline some of the NPCs will openly say that Omikron is a computer game ( while others will tell you that it is not :D) and it is the integral part of the plot.  It is quite worth playing the game just to discover this particular story gambit. To conclude: I cannot say whether Omikron is a good game or not. It is certainly an ambitious one.  It is noticeable that lot of work has been put into Quantic Dream’s first child. Still, one can’t help but notice that the later part of the game is significantly weaker, just as if authors ran out of ideas in the end. It doesn’t help that the puzzles in the final chapter of the game are EXTREMELY annoying ( For example – AND THERE WILL BE SPOILERS as I am describing two most annoying riddles in the game – at one point you are required to run around one of the districts, without the use of cabs, looking for four symbols – this task takes more or less half an hour, while solving the riddle when you know the symbols – no more than a minute. Ten minutes later you need to find a gem  - in the chamber where you can get it, there are approximately 20 chests with 20 similar gems – of course the game gives you hints as to which one you should choose but these are quite vague and you are not told in any way whether you picked the right one – and the place where you use the said gem is one hour ahead into gameplay. So yes, if you chose poorly you will be running right back. Or RAGEquit. Anyways, SPOILERS OUT).         If you are still planning to finish this game, it should take around 15 hours. It took me some more time since I decided to lose all the battles and check out the outcomes. My recommendation in this case is: buy this game (discounted!)  to check out where the authors of Indigo Prophecy, Heavy Rain and Beyond: Two Souls started. Play to discover that one major plot twist.  After that, there is not much Omikron has to offer. Be warned: I finished this one solely because I loved it OH SO MUCH back then in primary school.

												First let me start off by saying that Omikron is quite a unique game.  It is quite a trippy game.  The atmosphere of the Omikron world is something of uglyness and beauty at the same time.  The graphics are dated, but even when this game first came out the graphics looked a bit dated anyway.  This isn't necessarily a bad thing though.  The way the camera angles flow and just the general movement and weird textures and sounds in the game really kind of blend together to make Omikron stand out as a very unique looking game.  So instead of thinking "God these graphics suck!", I end up thinking "What a crazy artistic look this game has!".Omikron is also a very unique playing game as well.  It has a relatively large set of city maps to explore somewhat sandbox style.  The story itself plays out pretty linear from what I can tell, but there are alot of different areas to explore and site see.  There are plenty of interactions to be had with random people on the streets and whatnot just for the hell of it.  Some of these people you may end up becomming if you die complete with that person's attributes (which can be either a good or a bad thing depending on who you come back as, however you can "level up" your character somewhat anyway).  If you don't like who you come back to life as, you can find another person to be too.  You can hail a cab to get around or just run around instead.  There are a few things to do around the cities like watching an Omikron David Bowei do an underground show at a club (again, just for the hell of it).  Another thing you can do around the city is go fight in a tournament semi-Tekken style (although don't expect to enjoy it nearly as much as Tekken).   And if going from playing an almost GTA3 style feel of an adventure game to Tekken style tournament fighting wasn't enough, Omikron also has you fight some of the main combat situations in the game as a first person shooter (although a very crappy and hard to control fps).  Luckily, there aren't too many fps situations to worry about from what I've played.  Most of the game is adventure story driven playing instead of being a ton of combat situations.  The adventure story parts of the game are what I like about Omikron by far the most anyway.  Would I recomment this game?  Yes I would.  This game has it's faults no doubt, but if you can get past the awkward controls, bad camera angles, limited numbers of saves system, the hard to read fonts in the game, and all the other little quirks about the game, then you might find yourself liking this game at the same time.  So yeah Omikron definately tried to experiment with a new flavor of gameplay (some elements favorable, some elements  not so favorable), but overall I like their ideas they put into the different aspects of the game.  Catch it on sale for like $2.50 on Steam like I did.

												My feelings towards Omikron are very mixed. It is certainly one of the most unique games I've played... but it's a bit too unique for my liking. What I mean is, the game has a lot of variety- but not a lot of variety in it's actual gameplay. There are sections where you walk around and talk to people, sections where you swim, sections where you shoot enemies, and sections where you fight Mortal Kombat style. But there isn't much variation to this at all, and each gameplay has some hick in it; something that makes it really clunky to play around with.The graphics are fine in Omikron. I have no problem with them. But my problem is the animation. Faces make strange expressions and people over-emote by gesturing wildly. It's almost comical to watch at times. As far as stories go, Omikron's is the most involving I've played. It goes to great lengths to make sure that you know that you are NOT playing a game, but interacting with a very real world with very real consequences... but that had no effect on me, as I would often correct my mistakes by booting my old save up and trying again. And the design of the world and flow of the story is way too vague for me. A lot of the game almost requires you to look up a game guide, as the answers to a lot of the puzzles are borderline impossible. And sometimes just trying to find out what EXACTLY you have to do next in order to progress the story can be a massive pain, as you don't telepathically know what the game is requiring you to do.As far as the world and lore of Omikron goes, it's fine, but it has the same problem that Dragon Age: Origins only suffered slightly from- reading. A good lore can be told with subtlties between characters and showing in the dispaly of the world itself. I'd rather see mages practice magic than go to a library and study and make my own damn Beshe'm. (And I PERSONALLY want to know the people who knew how to make a flipping Besehe'm with no guide because none of the stuff I did to make it made any sense at all!)I personally don't like Omikron for it's faults. If it wanted it's consequences to matter, well I'd applaud Quantic Dream for doing a much better job of getting that across in Heavy Rain years later. But as Quantic's first production, Omikron suffers from some massive problems as a game, but it still has charm to it. There is freedom in the open world of Omikron, characters can be fun to interact with, and there is a certain draw I had to the game before I got really tired of playing it really fast- since the missions for The Awakened can get repetitive very quickly.If you want a gaming experience like none you've played before, Omikron is certainly one to fill that desire. But as far as great games go, I'm pretty sure Omikron won't stand the test of time to become a legend.

You move with the arrow keys, space to jump, Q to fight and Tab to access your inventory, very annoying controls. The game mostly involves you moving from one location to another and investigating an area. Sometimes the game has fighting sequences which look like they're taken from the old fighting games and sometimes there are shooting sequences, which put me off greatly. The game looks interesting however the gameplay does put me off. The game also has limited saves which will put off some people, including me...Omikron - The Nomad Soul looks interesting but with its gameplay issues and other things, the game did put me off just after an hour of playtime, some people might like but some others might not. 												For a game that's 15 years old, it still holds up. The story has a fairly silly premise, but is executed fairly well, and is fully voice-acted. David Bowie's cameos are fantastic, but the concerts will drag if you're not into his stuff. Even when he's not involved, the music is still fairly well composed. The controls haven't aged poorly, and the only complaint is that it's built for a gamepad, however, the controls are rebindable, so that's not a big deal. The shooting segments are somewhat awkward, but it may just be personal experience, since I haven't played the game for over 10 years. Puzzles are sometimes cryptic, but the solution generally presents itself in some format, as long as the player's been diligent about picking up EVERYTHING. The lip-sync gets pretty laughable, but it's impressive for a game this old, considering it animates the entire face.The open world is interesting to explore, though it can get a bit tedious since there isn't much to do outside the main story. Variation between the multiple characters is great, and players can always find someone who is fully capable, or at the very least, looks like a badass.I'd recommend this game to anyone who loves classic adventure games or David Bowie.

												I had this game years ago, but always had a problem getting it to run on my PC because of the ultra-realisitc graphics and 3D models of 1999.  I know: it's just NOT possible for graphics to ever get any more advanced that this.  Am I right?  Because my computer just could not handle the 32 MB of RAM needed to play this beast, I was only ever able to play it on Dreamcast, but is among my favourite games of all time, ranking just below the original Fallout.  That's just how good it is!It's a game that features David Bowie, his music, and his wife is a playable character.  What more is needed?  Nothing, I tell you.  After all these years now I'm able to play the game on PC without problems.  I dusted off my strategy guide (because I still have the strategy guide for this game) and entered heaven once more.I remeber the game being much more difficult when I was younger, but this game is not about struggling to advance further in the game, it is to experience the narrative.  Made by QuanticDream, the company known for its Hollywood-esque cinematic games like Deus Ex, Fahrenheit (or Indigo Prophecy), and Heavy Rain, just to name a few.  However, unlike Heavy Rain and Fahrenheit, you do actually get to play this game instead of going through quick-time events and occasionally getting to walk.  Nomad Soul (or Omikron: The Nomad Soul) requires strategy, it has timed events, gun combat, hand-to-hand combat reminiscent of Virtua Fighter, action events.  Basically this game is cross-genre hybrid of gaming types and it tries to balance them the best it can, though because of the tank controls (Yes, tank controls), things that require precision timing can be unfair. The game is fully-immersive.  You play as multiple characters throughout the game and each one has different strengths and weaknesses.  You, the player, are thrust into this world where you can go to the store to buy things, hang out at the bar, listen to some music, visit your apartment flat, do side missions, or just go through the plot.  The game has a similar feel to Shenmue where you can completely live in this game and ignore the main plot and go have fun in all the different locations.  The game really feels like a city.  There is obvious draw from Blade Runner in the game's design.The game offers some of the old-school-iest things in gaming that you just don't see anymore.  You have limited saves and checkpoints.  The game will require you to find rings to get more saves.  There does come to a point where you will have, like, 30 rings so as long as you play a good chunk of the game each session, you will not use up all your rings.  This really is not for the person who likes to save their game around every corner.  Be prepared to reload just so you don't waste all your rings.  These rings also act as continues, so again, reloading your last save is sometimes better than wasting all your rings. RIP Bowie!

Omikron's purported innovation and originality amount to nothing more than the senseless combination of unrelated but very familiar play styles. Omikron combines several types of gameplay with limited success. It's a 3D third-person adventure game with one-on-one fighting and shooting sequences. These conversation sequences, which cut from the game's standard third-person perspective to first-person close-up shots, feature detailed 3D characters that look really good. the game's much-ballyhooed soundtrack provided by legendary musician David Bowie and collaborator Reeves Gabrels isn't as good as you might expect. It lacks variety and matches the city's nondescript futuristic appearance with similarly forgettable techno. A few new Bowie songs are also part of Omikron's score and are effective if extraneous as Bowie's in-game alter ego performs them in concert, in-game.
